Preparation is but one factor, it would appear, in a successful weekend, up in the woods.  When accessing the inaccessible, there is little that can be taken for granted. reviewText: The characters are more developed in the excellent book by James Dickey, but this is a good movie version. The story is actually a modern telling of the biblical allegory of Adam and Eve and their expulsion from the Garden of Eden. It is about gaining knowledge and independence while paying the price of innocence and childish dependence. Four types of "civilized" men decide to spend a weekend in the wilderness. Three of them feel concerned about comfort and safety, but one reminds them of the dangers of their safe but boring city paradise. They feel yearnings they don't quite understand for a more natural paradise; given their lack of experience they think of Nature as mostly benevolent. Ultimately they face an arbitrary Nature and their own primitive humanity.This film is not a mere adventure/thriller/survival story. There are no easy metaphors like eating the fruit from the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil. These men experience good and evil firsthand, and just like Adam and Eve, they are expelled from the Garden forever. There is even a flood at the end! But as in the bible story, the flood does not destroy the seeds of evil. Parts of the story are shocking, but they are necessary to make the point. Pay attention to the subtle touches in the film: it is no accident or coincidence that no matter what goes on between people, the river keeps flowing and the birds keep chirping.Some movie trivia: the sheriff is played by author James Dickey, and he also taught Burt Reynolds and Jon Voight how to shoot a bow. The boy playing the banjo was not an actor; he was the real thing. But for the sake of authenticity another boy's more expert hands were playing the banjo - he was crouched and hidden behind the boy. As much as I've tried I can't see through this trick! Also, I don't know why the song is called "Dueling Banjos." The guitar and banjo complement each other so well I've always thought it should be called "Dueting Banjos."

reviewText: John Boorman's "Deliverance" is not a National Geographic film celebrating the beauty of nature. It is a film that deals entirely with a different kind of nature - the darker aspects of human nature. Lewis (Burt Reynolds) is an urbanite who fancies himself a man of the outdoors. To showcase his masculinity, he takes a group of friends with him on a canoe trip down a whitewater river in Georgia. The rest of the gang: Ed (John Voight), Drew (Ronnie Cox), and Bobby (Ned Beatty) are bona-fide urbanites totally out of their element in the wilderness. They make no pretensions about being the outdoors type because they know they are not. Lewis on the other hand, never abandons his charade and calmly reassures them that nature can be tamed.At the outset, Lewis is proved correct. The canoe trip proves to be an exhilarating experience. However, disaster looms on the horizon, not by the natural hazards around the men, but by man himself. The four men soon find themselves victims of the denizens of the non-civilized world and their recreational trip turns into tragedy. Hard choices have to be made from the events that transpire. Three of the men return from the trip with their preconceptions of life forever altered and less one friend.John Boorman's film still maintains much of its raw power to this day. Some of its violence has been muted due to the common sight of similar violence in mainstream entertainment and real-life but the foreboding atmosphere created by the film still chills with every viewing. The film is also a welcome reminder of just how good an actor Burt Reynolds was in his prime. Many people forget that this was the top male actor of the late 1970's and early 1980's due to the fact that he was involved in so many forgettable projects since his heyday. To see him while he was still a passionate and dedicated actor is thrilling. Mention must also be made of John Voight who also distinguishes himself and proves that his performance in "Midnight Cowboy" was no fluke. Finally, no critique of "Deliverance" is complete without a mention of "Dueling Banjos", but what more needs to be said in that regard?

reviewText: Deliverance (1972) has a well deserved reputation for being a terrific movie.  And while the years may have taken some of the edge and impact from John Boorman's film, the realism and terrific performances, make the film adaptation of James Dickey's story essential viewing, for lovers of suspense and wilderness horror, as four friends in the backwoods of Georgia, take a journey down a river that changes their lives forever.Director Boorman takes an excellent screenplay, and then does a fantastic job of bringing it to the screen with a high degree of realism.  The dialog seems so natural, as Lewis Medlock (Burt Reynolds), Ed Genty (Jon Voight), Bobby Trippe (Ned Beaty), and Drew Balinger (Ronny Cox), friends from the city, are looking to take a trip downriver in a pair of canoes.  The acting performances are outstanding, headed by Reynolds and Voight, with newcomers Ronny Cox, and Ned Beatty both amazingly good, in their feature film debuts.The way films were made in the 1970's involved more real action, but even so, the level of realism in Deliverance is remarkable.  The actors are actually in the canoes, travelling down the river, and navigating around rocks and through rapids.  Then when the canoes tip over, they actors not stuntmen, are in the raging waters trying to avoid getting killed, or cut up on the rocks.  Throughout the film, Boorman does a great job of positioning his cameras to capture the edginess of the action, even when boats are moving on the river, or men are in the water.The notorious pig squeal rape scene, is still quite memorable and disturbing, as Beaty gives a stirring performance.  Ed's inability to free himself seems a little suspect though.  Other questionable moments include Medlock's sudden back injury, Drew's mysterious tumble into the water, and Ed's extremely fake looking accidental self-inflicted wound, and subsequent fall into the river, instead of the rocks below.  The group also makes a pretty weak effort at digging.  But otherwise, most of what happens seems pretty real and credible.  The film has several interesting transitions, one occurs when the group is attacked and Lewis uses his hunting bow, another is when they decide to cover up what has happened, and a third when Lewis is injured, and Ed has to take over, putting Voight in the spotlight.There is some relief when the survivors get clear and reach civilization, but there is a cloud over them that may never leave, as they wait to be cleared by the authorities.  A story of the loss on innocence and survival, Deliverance is one of the classic coming of age stories from the 1970's. reviewText: Deliverance, it seems, has indelibly embedded itself in popular consciousness, despite its being nearly as old as me. The banjo-totin' cretin with fingers of fury, Ned Beatty's harrowing porcine approximations, vengeful crackers stalking the woods above the river--these images, enhanced for home audiences by a first-rate digital transfer and crystal-clear audio remix, have aged well--much better, in fact, than Burt Reynolds, one of the film's actors, whom seeing sans hairpiece and porn mustache was uncanny--and have, I think, taken on an added relevance for these times of dire ecological prospects. The impending demise of the town of Aintry, Georgia and the river running through it at the hands of a hydroelectric utility is a harbinger our fate writ small.Deliverance is also interesting for being one of a slew of '70s films whose subject matter is those marginal types stalking the hinterlands, and the various perversities around which their aggregate identities are organized. In addition to Deliverance, the ' 70s saw the release of The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, The Hills Have Eyes, and, Friday the 13th. Admittedly, Deliverance distinguishes itself from this company in its thematic content, which aims for psychological and philosophical depth, as opposed to mere exploitation. The existential glosses of Deliverance are nothing short of masterful. The images of dying and death have an agonizing physicality to them, and the dead bodies themselves seem almost to make the screen sag under their insistent corporeality (The actors portraying the two key hicks deserved Oscars for their utterly convincing expirations). Such touches elevate Deliverance above the sensationalism it flirts with.Intercalated with the theme of masculine self-actualization, are those of man's collisions with both nature and civilization, either having the power to undo an individual. For the hillbillies, Georgia's hill country is a mis-en-scène of very palpable degeneracy, while for the four vacationers, the city is the same. The gap-toothed menace of the lustful rustics finds its complement in Ned Beatty's flabby lubricity. The city takes what the country makes, and vice versa. This is most clearly seen in the neat narrative symmetry at work between Burt Reynolds and John Voigt's respective characters. Oppositions in this movie are never facile, though, and one is left with the sense that the Weltanschauung expressed in it is one eternal Manichean struggle; civilization consumes nature (the hydroelectric dam destroying the river), and is in turn consumed by nature (this is at work at many levels in the film, but the most striking image is the rising waters around Aintry). Viewing Deliverance again has led me to muse upon the historical and culture dimensions of the '70s, and what anxieties the film and those of its ilk capture.

reviewText: Four city-boy businessmen unwittingly take themselves on a canoe trip to barbarity along a remote river in Georgia. Adapted from the magnificent novel by James Dickey, "Deliverance" employs the river and the  surrounding forest as brutal devices to gradually strip its pampered  characters of all traces of civilization so that they, and we, can learn  what lies beneath their cultural facades. What are we capable of doing in  the absence of structured society, when we must answer only to ourselves?  John Boorman shot this movie in sequence, and there's a powerful sense of  progression along the cruel river. The actors, the film crew and the  audience are all transported relentlessly from the light into a Conrad-like  heart of darkness. It's up to each of us to see what we can discover by the  time we emerge. The character Lewis, portrayed in a fine performance by  Burt Reynolds, concisely sets the stage with "Sometimes you have to  lose yourself before you can find anything." Macho poet Dickey  collaborated tempestuously but productively with Boorman to bring this  wonderful work to the screen. Neither of them ever surpassed  "Deliverance" and it must surely rank as one of the best movies  ever made. To learn more about Dickey, the novel, and the film, see the  recent book "Summer of Deliverance" by his equally talented son,  Christopher. I would also recommend that the film be viewed as a double  bill with Spielberg's "Duel", which replaces Dickey's river with  a monstrous truck on the backroads of California.
summary: Life lessons from John Boorman's best work

reviewText: There is no adult language in this review, but the material might offend some readers.As I grow older and more affectless, and having seen too many action films in the last 38 years, I find that "Deliverance" has lost much of its visceral impact. This isn't Boorman's, Dickey's, or the actors' faults, but the serious way in which the book and film treat the material. At the time "Deliverance" was released, it was a genuinely exciting and disturbing film. It isn't a trashy exploitation flick, but we've seen enough of the latter ("Total Recall", for example) to have distorted our tastes.I'd like to cover two points that have had little or no discussion. The first is the author's attitude towards Appalachian people and their society. Like James Dickey, I'm an educated intellectual who used to share the common view that these people were violent, stupid, inbred hicks. "Fat Bobby" is the primary exponent of this view, and -- as each of the four principals represents an aspect of James Dickey's personality & character -- one wonders to what extent the author accepts this view.The story does little to present Appalachian people in a positive light. At best, we're left pitying them, rather than seeing anything of value in their way of life (other than the weakly positive impression left by the communal meal at the end). Certainly the sheriff's (portrayed by Dickey) warning not to ever do anything like this again can be interpreted a number of ways, including "I hate city folk, and I'll likely shoot you if I ever see you again." (Or is that "ag'in"?) It's hard not to believe that Dickey saw backwoods folk as too-often dangerous, and to be feared, if for no other reason than that they were "closer to nature".My own experience over the last 38 years, based on belonging to a buckskinning club, and seeing films about rural working-class people, has changed my mind. People are pretty much people, and the only legitimate criticism one might make of Appalachians is their lack of intellectual sophistication. Even /that/ is questionable -- if you haven't read the classic "Pissing in the Snow", a collection of Appalachian humor, do so. This humor is not the product of mentally dull people.Which brings us to the story's central conceit... "You rape nature, nature rapes you back." Literally. One can believe backwoodsmen might be upset by city people invading their turf, to the point of shoving guns in their faces and chasing them off. * But the thought that they would use the opportunity to commit rape doesn't strike me as particularly plausible, even if the rape is intended as violent retribution (rather than as a sexual act). "Deliverance" seems to portray it as sexual -- the good-looking "mountain man" strokes Bobby's face and squeezes a nipple, and his "foreplay" is more comic than vicious.In Boorman's commentary, he says that the film is "about" the way men have the urge to do things that are characteristically male. Does this include rape? And if a woman isn't available, will a man do? -- In this case, the least-manly of the group, the one most-resembling a popular farm animal. There is thus an implicit justification of Bobby's brutalization, both as punishment for turf invasion, and as an expression of "natural" male sexuality.The men's arguing about covering up the killing also seems oddly double-edged. Drew (Ronny Cox) sees it as murder, plain and simple, despite the fact that Bobby had been raped and Ed was about to be. The implication is that men have no right to use lethal force against someone simply raping them, but not otherwise threatening them. Of course, the assailants were armed, but whether they would have just "had their fun" and let Bobby and Ed live is unknowable. Nevertheless, it seems odd that Ed feels guilty about the killing -- or is just that he's worried about being caught?Dickey approached the director and actors and told them all -- in strict secrecy, of course! -- that everything in the story had actually happened to him -- including, presumably, being raped by a backwoodsman. Actually, none of it ever happened, but Dickey's fantasy perhaps tells us something of how he views "masculinity" and may reveal an unconscious desire to demonstrate that feral males found him sexually attractive. **"Brokeback Mountain" plays very much as an inversion of "Deliverance". Though both are about man's relationship to "nature" -- both the natural world and the inner nature of human beings -- the former's tag line -- "Love is a force of nature" -- could easily be inverted to one for the latter: "Violence is a force of nature". The love and violence are both uncontrollable, and expressed as male/male rape.A comparative analysis of these films might be worthwhile, focusing on the nature of Nature, what man's relationship to it is, what is and what is not "natural", and other pointy-headed-intellectual issues. Anyone up for it?PS: Perhaps the best thing about "Deliverance" is that it resulted in the discovery of Ned Beatty. I've never seen him a role where he was not absolutely convincing. He is truly one of the great American actors.* The story conveniently overlooks the fact that once the river has been flooded, a substantial chunk of hunting property -- and possibly farmland -- will be lost. This alone is justification for hating city folk. One need not assume any innate violence.** James Dickey was tall, heavyset, and plain. William McKinney, the actor playing the rapist, is handsome, wiry, and graceful. Whether or not he was intentionally cast for it, his sexual attractiveness cannot be ignored.

reviewText: RELEASE DATE: 1972DIRECTOR: John BoormanWRITER: James Dickey (novel and screenplay)CAST: Jon Voight, Ned Beatty, Burt Reynolds and Ronny Cox.RUNTIME: 1 hour, 50 minutes.PLOT: Four guys from the Atlanta area take a canoe/camping trip in the NE Georgia wilderness. When they run into a couple malevolent hillbillies their fun time turns into a disturbing test of survival.I didn't see "Deliverance" until almost two decades after its 1972 release. I didn't know anything about the film or anyone who had seen it, but it looked like a potentially good adventure story so I finally decided to rent it.The first Act plays out as you would expect, four guys escaping the shackles of urban life enjoying a canoe trip, and then -- WHAM -- Act 2 hits you like a ton of bricks. When I first viewed the film I wasn't braced for this scene. In fact, it was so disturbing that it pretty much ruined the rest of the picture for me. I watched it until the end but - that scene - left me dazed and detached. Viewing it again recently I was fully braced for - that scene - and was therefore able to appreciate the film.MISCELLANEOUS THOUGHTS:- Burt Reynolds is great as the macho protagonist Lewis, but he's largely missing during the third act and epilogue. The unassuming Ed (Voight) takes the reigns as deliverer, with Bobby (Beatty) lending a helping hand.- The film was shot on the Chattooga River in NE Georgia, which borders South Carolina. The gorge is located in Tallulah Gorge State Park  15 miles West of Walhalla, SC (you can actually see it via satellite on Google maps -- check it out). The dilapidated town in the epilogue is Sylva, NC, 45 miles north of the gorge. Needless to say, lush Eastern locations.- After the distubing scene a moral crisis takes place in the remote forest where the four members of the party must vote on a decision. Lewis (Reynolds) and Drew (Cox) make their cases and the other two must choose. Count me with Lewis. At first glance it would seem that Drew is arguing the side of the wimpy moralist, i.e. contact local law enforcement and allow the courts to settle the matter. Is this the real reason he takes this position or is it simply because he doesn't want to risk becoming an "accessory to a crime"? Actually, Lewis is no less the moralist -- after all, he makes a moral judgment and unhesitatingly acts -- it's just that he refuses to risk allowing the local authorities and a potential inbred jury (likely related somehow to the hillbillies) twist his just and necessary actions into a crime.- The writer of the story, James Dickey, effectively plays the towering Southern Sheriff in the epilogue.- The Deluxe Edition dvd includes an excellent 4-part documentary that runs about 45 minutes. All principle cast members are interviewed, as well as director Boorman and the son of James Dickey. By all accounts Dickey had a forceful personality and intimidating presence. He kept calling the actors by the names of the people they were playing even while not filming. One night in a pub he kept referring to Reynolds as "Lewis" from across the room and Burt refused to answer him. Dickey came up to his table and got in his face. Angered, Burt cussed at him and told him to quit calling him Lewis. Dickey paused for a moment and responded, "That's exactly what Lewis would have said" and walked away.- "Wrong Turn" is a modern horror film that, generally speaking, tackles the same subject as "Deliverance." The problem with the former film is that it's full of horror cliches and cops an unrealistic vibe. Don't get me wrong, it's an entertaining film but I was never able to buy into the story as a potential reality; hence, I didn't find it horrifying at all. "Deliverance," on the other hand, is totally realistic from beginning to end and is successfully horrifying precisely because it COULD happen.- Speaking of realism, Roger Ebert heavily criticized the scene in "Deliverance" where Ed (Voight) climbs up the rock gorge, arguing that it was totally unrealistic. Is he serious? He needs to get out more. I'm older than Ed in the film and could climb those rocks fairly easily (I'm not bragging, just pointing out that Ebert's criticism is not valid for anyone who's in remotely decent shape).- Also speaking of realism, if you suffer from ADHD and need constant (unrealistic) action scenes and goofy one-liners to maintain your attention, skip this one.- Lastly, "Deliverance" is going on 40 years old and hasn't dated at all. This is a timeless modern picture.PERSONAL GRADE: A
summary: Disturbing 1972 adventure on the Chattooga River
